hints.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

There are $\blueD{6}$ kids.

There are $\greenD{24}$ total balloon animals.


What is the $\purpleC{\text{size of the groups}}$?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths, a first tape labeled 24 and a second tape with six equal parts labeled with question marks. A curved bracket is across the bottom and the width of the second tape and is labeled with the words 6 equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}\times\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}= \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\blueD{6}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{24}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}=\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}$

So, $\greenD{24}\div \blueD{6}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many balloon animals Catie Clown made for each kid are: 

- $\blueD{6}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{24}$
- $\greenD{24}\div \blueD{6}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

question.content:
Catie Clown made the same number of balloon animals for each of the $6$ kids at the birthday party.  She made $24$ balloon animals.

**Which equations would help us find out how many balloon animals Catie Clown made for each kid?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
